results.title: Other olympics
results.creator_credit: Kevin Boulton, Australian Broadcasting Commission and Don Worley
results.brief_description: A look at the 1980 Olympics for the disabled held in Arnhem, Netherlands because Moscow declined the offer to stage the event, in which thousands of handicapped people competed in a wide range of events. The first Disabled games was held in London 1948, only 16 competetors, 1960 in Rome - 400 competetors, but, in 1980 over 42 countries competed. The partcipants included paraplegics, quadraplegics, amputees, people who have cerebal palsey, polio and varying degrees of blindness. It was at these games that users and wheelchair designers explored and exhibited new designs to assist the handicapped. H.R.H.Princess Margaritte opened the games which had the ideals of friendship, unity and sportsmanship. Many world records were broken. This program was narrated by Richard Morecroft.

results.title: Othello [Dubbed]
results.brief_description: Sergei Yutkevich liberates the play from the confines of the stage and uses realistic backgrounds to recreate Shakespeares “Port in Cyprus”. The text has been closely edited to concentrate attention on the relationship between Othello and Iago, and attention to visual details helps to underline the salient points of the original plot. Awarded the prize for direction at the 1956 Cannes Film Festival. Original music by Aram Khachaturyan. (Film is dubbed in English). Title and credits missing.

results.title: Othello (Perspective)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Shakespeare in Perspective Series”.
Designed to provide a greater understanding and appreciation of the play by placing it in its historical and social context and by stressing its relevance to a modern day audience. Perspective offered by Susan Hill, writer and broadcaster.

results.title: Othello
results.creator_credit: John Brabourne, Anthony Havelock-Allan and Stuart Burge
results.brief_description: National Theatre of Great Britain’s stage production of William Shakespeare’s play. Features Laurence Olivier, Maggie Smith, Derek Jacobi and Frank Finlay. Although the lighting is very dark at times making the action hard to discern, this dramatisation is very powerful and moving.

results.title: Oskar Fischinger. Volume 2
results.brief_description: Compilation of works by German avant-garde animator Oskar Fischinger, an inventive artist who performed his own research, including different animation techniques, 3D, optical sound and colour. The works on this tape include: “Muratti Privat” (1935) In this advertisement for smoking the cigarettes are arranged in a series of balletic movements. “War Experiments” (1921-26) An intriguing work (with a silent track) that utilises time-lapse and sliced wax-imagery. “Munchen-Berlin Wanderung” (1927) A journey from Munich to Berlin was documented by Fischinger, presenting a fascinating glimpse of 1920s Germany. “Study No. 5” (1930) Thousands of charcoal images were shot frame-by-frame in this fluid, musical and beautifully choreographed work. “Study No. 9” (1931) Synchronised to Brahms’ “Hungarian dance no 6”, the graceful images on screen create a dynamic work. “Study No. 12” (1932) A work by brothers Hans and Oscar, is clever and elegant, set to Rubenstein’s “Bride of Corinth”. “Komposition in Blau” (1935) Delightful, experimental piece, utilises contrasting colour and shape to present dynamic movement between forms, utilising numerous animation techniques. “American March” (1941) Geometric images shape shift to become irregular forms, set to an American anthem. “Organic Fragment” (1941) A series of line drawings and painted cells, using an array of shape and colour. “Mutoscope Reels” (c. 1945) A rich variety of imagery and effects, these reels are essentially a series animation drawings. “Muntz TV Commercial” (1952) Intriguing television commercial in black and white with original soundtrack.

results.title: Oskar Fischinger. Volume 1
results.brief_description: Compilation of works by German avant-garde animator Oskar Fischinger, who began experimenting visually from 1921, composing his well-known series of studies (Studie 1-13) from 1929-34. An inventive artist, Fischinger performed his own research, including different animation techniques, 3D, optical sound and colour. The works on this tape include: “Muratti greift ein = Muratti marches on” (1934). An advertising film, promoting the joys of smoking, Fischinger’s technique was to use real cigarettes with a toothpick inserted in one end, shot frame by frame. Music from Josef Bayer’s “Die Puppenfee”. “Spiritual constructions” (1927-29). Kaolin wax figures are modelled and manipulated on a glass sheet with lighting from beneath, rendering opaque shapes with fluid, continuous movement. “Study number 7” (1930-31). Various shapes, including dots, squares and lines, are gracefully and energetically transformed, flickering and curving across the screen, accompanied by Brahms’ Hungarian Dance No 5. “Study number 8” (1931) Complex and stunning work, presaged Fantasia, with an array of shapes humorously flitting hither and thither. “Kreise = Circles” (1933) A commercial commissioned by the Tolirag Theatre, Fischinger presents a free-form composition made of circles which interlink, flash, fly and surge past the viewer. “Allegretto” (1936) Fischinger’s first American film is a splendidly colourful affair, accompanied by a jazz soundtrack. “Motion painting no 1” (1947) This piece is about the evolution of a painting, literally a work in motion, as swirls, shapes and lines are continuously layered, creating new patterns and forms. An influential artist, Fischinger’s work is both visually spectacular and humorous.

results.title: Oscillators
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Radio Technician Training”.
Explains the basic principles of electronic oscillation and variations in oscillations are studied; functioning of a common circuit and tank circuit are explained by means of animation.

results.title: Oscar Niemeyer: architect of Brasilia
results.creator_credit: Allan King Associates and William Brayne
results.brief_description: In 1956 Brazilian architect Oscar Niemeyer joined with other Brazilians to build a new city and new society - Brasilia. Niemeyer continued to work toward the completion of the city, the buildings of which exhibit a high aesthetic impact that avoids American and European functional emphasis. His major disappointment is in the failure of the project to produce a new society - life in Brasilia remains stratified and formalised.
